verses.text: To show partiality is not good- yet a man will do wrong for a piece of bread.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 28
rsbNotes.text: 28:1–28 This chapter contains a heavier concentration of theological reflection than earlier chapters of proverbial sentences. Sometimes this is explicit, with references to God or to the law and righteousness. In other sentences it is more implicit, as in the contrast of the righteous and the wicked, which seems to assume the underlying providential order and judgment of God.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 28:21
rsbNotes.text: 28:21 See 18:5; 24:23, 24. Even a small bribe can have disastrous results in the maintenance of order and justice in society.

verses.text: A stingy man is eager to get rich and is unaware that poverty awaits him.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 28:22
rsbNotes.text:
28:22 A stingy man. A miser (23:6 note and text note).

poverty will come. The meaning is either that the miser lacks the wisdom to gain and keep wealth, or that God’s justice will not allow such a one to be rich (v. 20).
